description.narrative:
Approximate number of beneficiaries in the selected districts:
- 67.500 beneficiaries of constructed or rehabilitated water wells. - 80.000 beneficiaries of irrigation infrastructure improvement - 1.050 peace shura members as direct beneficiaries with 70% of the 200.000 inhabitants of the respective districts as indirect beneficiaries - 3,750 teachers as beneficiaries of peace building teaching.

In Afghanistan, this Reconstruction programme will focus on the following outcomes:
Outcome 1: Increased trust and cooperation among and within the various groups
Outcome 2: Reduction in conflict over land and water

The proposed programme will contribute to the improvement of human security by reducing conflict over land and water, through a comprehensive and appropriate package of interventions in three areas facing similar issues. These areas are selected districts of northern Afghanistan; Dar El Salaam and Kalamendo localities in North Darfur, Sudan; and Amudat District in the Karamoja region of north-eastern Uganda.

activity-date.narrative: The project received initial approval from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs on 28th June 2012 for a total amount of 60% of the proposed budget at the time of submission in March 2012. ZOA was then asked to submit a revised project plan by latest 15th September 2012. The Ministry notified ZOA of the approval of the revised plan on 16th November 2012, after which ZOA started implementation of the project. ZOA found it best to not start the revised project immediately after submission in September 2012 so not to run the risk of beginning project work on a wrong footing, we considered the operational risks of starting the project without having received the donor’s ultimate directions, too high. Therefore, we could only start full project preparations in second half of November.

location.ref: Afghanistan: Sar-E Pul and Jawzjan Provinces

policy-marker.narrative: The main objective is to contribute to the improvement of human security by reducing conflict over land and water, through a comprehensive and appropriate package of interventions

description.narrative: Access to water is increased
By the end of the project, year round safe drinking water availability per capita has increased by 15% in at least 50% of the targeted communities in Afghanistan and Sudan.

comment.narrative: As per report of W4P, as per baseline survey (end of August 2013): - 3.1 liter per capita in 20 villages of Sayyad district. - 2.5 liter per capita in 30 villages of Faizabad district
15%: increase (when compared to baseline) in water availability per capita 50%: of the targeted communities
971% increase of water availability 102% of the targeted communities

15%: increase (when compared to baseline) in water availability per capita 50%: of the targeted communities
During 2013 wells were rehabilitated and constructed in 32 villages. The water assessment (baseline) in August 2013 has to show the exact capacity of these wells.
15%: increase (when compared to baseline) in water availability per capita 50%: of the targeted communities
Total nr of targeted communities is 78. MTR result: - 9 liter per capita in 9 villages of Sayyad - 8 liter per capita in 19 villages of Faizabad

description.narrative: By the end of the project, dry season drinking water availability for livestock has increased by 15% in at least 50% of the targeted communities where livestock is a major livelihoods strategy.

comment.narrative: N/A:
15%: increase (when compared to baseline) in dry season drinking water availability for livestock 50%: of the targeted communities
Actual result is the average percentage of availability of water/day/animal, since baseline data for tough was not measurable
15%: increase (when compared to baseline) in dry season drinking water availability for livestock 50%: of the targeted communities

Actual result is the average percentage of availability of water/day/animal, since baseline data for tough was not measurable. A total of 3 troughs were constructed properly in Faizabad; these troughs provide 4290 liters of water for 1210 animal per day ( 3.5 liter per animal per day) for about 10 villages. There was not any trough in Faizabad before, but people have been watering their livestocks from irrigation canals so the baseline data for trough was not measurable.
15%: increase (when compared to baseline) in dry season drinking water vailability for livestock 50%: of the targeted communities
In 2013 troughs were constructed for livestock in 6 villages, but the increased water availability has to be determined during the August 2013 survey.
15%: increase (when compared to baseline) in dry season drinking water availability for livestock 50%: of the targeted communities

More than 100% increase has been achieved. Actual result is the average percentage of availability of water/day/animal, since baseline data for tough was not measurable. Animals from other provinces especially from Faryab province travelling to Sheberghan are also benefiting

description.narrative: By the end of the project, irrigation water availability has increased by 15% in at least 50% of the targeted communities thanks to different water conservation techniques.

comment.narrative: Will be baselined in Aug 2013 because of seasonality

Average increase of irrigation water availability in 100% of targeted villages is 43%
15%: increased (in comparison to baseline) irrigation water availability 50%: targeted communities
Implementation of irrigation infrastructures is in the phase of study and design.
15%: increased (in comparison to baseline) irrigation water availability 50%: targeted communities

In Khawja Du Koh the irrigation system was completely cut off due to the flooding in the spring 2014. Intervention of ZOA repaired the irrgation canal and 639 families were able to irrigate their land. For these families increase of available water was 100% as without the intervention they would have none.

description.narrative: Capacity of grassroots conflict mitigation and prevention mechanisms is enhanced
By the end of the project 75% of the people in each community can identify and have confidence in the relevant grassroots bodies

comment.narrative: N/A
At this point it is too early in the project to expect people to have confidence in the new bodies/ Peace Shuras.
Average result
Average result

Survey results show that: • 319 of 620 (51%) male and 246 of 464 (53%) female respondents could identify the name of Peace Shura that works on conflict resolution and prevention in the community. • 267 of 620 (43%) male and 209 of 464(45%) female respondents were able to give the correct name of the Peace Shura that works on conflict resolution and prevention in the community • 211 of 620( 34%) male and 204 of 464 (44%) female respondents were able to mention the right name of the chairman of the Peace Shura.

description.narrative: By the end of the project, 75% of the targeted members of Shuras can explain how they will use what they learnt about conflict mitigation and prevention in practice.

comment.narrative: N/A
According to survey: • 26 of 51 (51%) male and 32 of 52 (62%) female respondents could give good examples of practical applications in the past and in the future.

description.narrative: Six months after completion of peace education, 50% of trainees in the target area in Afghanistan are able to reproduce key messages and explain how they apply this in their own lives

comment.narrative: N/A

Peace education in schools was started in the past month as the approval of the Ministry of Education took a long time. Students from 4 schools in Khawja Du Koh and 2 schools in Faizabad received the Peace Eduction, however this indicator can only be measured after 6 months.

description.narrative: Capacity of local leadership and civil society to manage land and water resources in a sustainable, effective, equitable and conflict sensitive way is enhanced
At least 50% of agreed capacity strengthening measures with partner organisations have been implemented by the partner

comment.narrative: N/A: End of project indicator

A three days capacity building workshop has conducted in Kabul on 15 to 17 of Dec 2015. The workshop was focused on HR policy and montoring mechanism . The training workshop was based on the agreement signed before with partner organization.
All of the trainings in capacity building have been implemented by local partner organisation SDO.

During 2015 and 2016 a series of 12 Capacity Building workshops were held in Kabul with local NGOs including SDO. At the beginning an organizational assessment was done by ZOA staff (Programme Advisor and Project Coordinator) to establish the needs of the different local NGOs. At the end of the program an external evaluation was done, showing that 82% of the trainees are using the new acquired knowledge in their work.
In contract with local partner SDO it was agreed to have 3 trainings during this year, while only 2 have been realized.

description.narrative: By the end of the project, 60% of water management committees are able to demonstrate learned skills and knowledge

comment.narrative: N/A: end of project indicator
As per MTR result: 100% of respondent could demonstrate knowledge on clean water and 83% of respondents could demonstrate knowledge on preparing ORS
At the average of 82% of male and 82% of female water management committees members were able to demonstrate correctly learnt skills and knowledge .

Based on end line survey:82% of male and 82% of female water management committees responded correctly regarding the learnt skills - responsibilities of committees and awareness of importance of safe drinking water and hygiene related massages.
Water management committees have not been trained yet.

description.narrative: Groups are empowered to realize their rights and duties
By the end of the project, 50% of the people in the Afghan target area can produce key information about their rights within the framework of Sharia Rule of Law.

comment.narrative: This is an indicative figure because the relation between the indicator and the questions in the baseline survey is not completely correct. In reality this figure could be a lot lower.
27% is average result (male/female)
50% is average result (male/female)
50% is average result (male/female)
Measuring turned out to be very sensitive, as it refers to a religious law. SDO did a baseline survey and for this indicator the results were extremely high, as it is difficult to be specific.

description.narrative: No progress yet on outcome/output level as in description due to a revision of the project plan by latest 15th September 2012. The Ministry notified ZOA of the approval of the revised plan on 16th November 2012, after which ZOA started implementation of the project. Therefore below some general information on implementation per country: AFGHANISTAN During the project reporting period, ZOA focused in Afghanistan on a few areas: establishing the partnership with Sanayee Development Organisation (SDO), start of the baseline survey and organisation of inter-country working relationships with the country organisations in Sudan and Uganda. In Afghanistan, ZOA is working with the Community Development Councils to provide its members with basic conflict resolution training in Uruzgan and Saripul provinces, but we have not been able to expand much more on these activities due to the complex context of the country and lack of funding. Now, with the community peace building experience of a senior staff member and with funding for the reconstruction project available, this will change.

description.narrative: By the end of the project, 50% of the targeted agricultural households have increased their annual cereal crop production by at least 10%

comment.narrative: Rain-fed: 17% / Irrigated: 24%
An increase of 9% in crop production in 50% of targeted villages.
An increase of 10% when compared to the baseline

No data about the increase of crop production yet. The interventions in the irrigation systems have only started in the last 3 months of 2014 and with the agriculture production taken place mainly in the winter/spring season the results of such interventions will only become measureable in August 2015.
